subject: BoJ Minutes from March 14th-15th meeting states will take time to hit the 2% price target, while most members agreed momentum to reaching the target is maintained and that they must persistently continue with its powerful monetary easing
content:
• One member said must maintain easy policy with an eye on the side effects such as on financial institutions  and market functioning.
  • One member said there was room to revise the way BoJ conducts bond purchases.
  • One member said central bank must be prepared to act if downside risks to the economy and prices were materializing.

Automotive Holdings (AHG AT) - Co. board unanimously recommended improved offer from AP Eagers (APE AT). (Newswires)

CSR (CSR AT) - Co. FY net AUD 78.0mln vs. Exp. AUD 123.0mln, rev. from continued operations rose 4% to AUD 2.3bln, Co. also declares final dividend of AUD 0.13/Shr. (Newswires)

Elsewhere, the Co. said it was pleased at how its business is performing in all regions and across its portfolio in response to claims by Bayberry Capital Partners that the Co. shares were overvalued by more than 50% and that it was conducting practices to inflate its sales figures. (SMH)

ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include BoJ Minutes from March Meeting, RBNZ Rate Decision and Chinese Trade Data
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

Chinese Premier Li said that economic stabilisation is not 'solid' yet. (Newswires)

China's Vice Premier Liu He is to go the US for trade talks, for the 9th - 10th May. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor noted that the possibility of an escalation of China-US trade war is seriously increasing and that the situation is more tense than the western media speculated. However, the editor also suggested that US side still has a willingness to reach a deal and that Thursday will be the decisive moment between US and China. (Global Times)

Senior White House officials described US President Trump as deadly serious about increasing the tariffs on China, according to Politico’s Morning Money. (Politico)

New Zealand Dairy Prices 0.4% (Prev. 0.5%) and Whole Milk Powder Index -0.5% (Prev. -0.7%). (Newswires) 

 

UK/EU

UK government spokesperson said that talks with the opposition Labour Party were constructive and will continue on Wednesday. (Newswires)

UK Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay was said to have raised the prospect of leaving the EU without a deal in October, although there was a push back from Business Secretary Clark who said it was clear now that that couldn't happen, while it was also reported that there was no substantive discussion of cross party talks at the cabinet meeting, according to BBC's Laura Kuenssberg. (Twitter)

UK opposition Labour party were reportedly playing down the prospects of a cross-party deal being struck and suggested that all the briefing over the weekend came from the government’s side, while Labour sources also dismissed there was a temporary customs union offer and stated that all the government was offering is what’s already on the table, according to the Daily Mirror's Pippa Crerar. (Twitter)

The 1922 Committee is reportedly tied on the issue of changing the rules for a leadership challenge, according to ITV's Paul Brand. (Twitter)

There were some unverifiable sources that suggested UK PM May has resigned, although a PM May Spokesperson later stated he was not aware of any speculation UK PM May is to step-down. (Newswires)

BoE's Haldane said it would be deeply arrogant for MPC to say markets are wrong on interest rates due to economic uncertainty and that it is very reasonable for others to take a different view on the economic outlook to the BoE. (Newswires)

Italy Deputy PM Salvini said the government will cut taxes in 2019 even if it means breaking the EU's 3% deficit to GDP limit. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

US API weekly crude stocks (29 Apr) 2.81M vs. Exp. 1.2M (Prev. +6.8M). (Newswires)

EIA raised forecast for global oil demand for 2019 by 20k BPD and now sees a 1.38mln BPD Y/Y increase, while it raised forecast for 2020 global oil demand by 80k BPD and now sees 1.53mln BPD Y/Y increase. (Newswires) 

 

GEOPOLITICS

US will reportedly deploy B-52 bombers in the Middle East over Iran concerns and it was also reported that Iran is likely moving short-range ballistic missiles aboard boats in the Persian Gulf. In related news, there were also reports that Iran's Foreign Ministry is to announce 'diminishing commitments' to the nuclear deal which will be announced on Wednesday to the 5 remaining signatories. (Newswires) 

 

US

Fed's Clarida (Voter, Neutral) said the US economy is in a good place and that he sees temporary factors in recent soft inflation, while he added we don't see a strong case to move rates in either direction and that focus is on getting inflation up to 2% with the Fed the adjust policy as required in order to meet this objective. (Newswires)

Fed's Quarles (Voter, Neutral) said he sees current level of inflation as being at the Fed's goals. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (Non-vote, Dove) expects the US economy to remain healthy and does not see a recession coming and commented that the US should start to moderate debt growth. (Newswires) 

 

MARKET RECAP

Boeing (BA) shares were weighed down as the aircraft maker was downgraded at Barclays and faced criticism from American Airline pilots for poor communication regarding safety features on the 737 Max aircraft. American insurance Group (AIG) finished with strong gains as the insurer posted strong earnings. Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) were under pressure after reporting earnings that missed analyst expectations on both the top and bottom line. Allergan (AGN) also performed poorly on the day, despite reporting a beat on both the top and bottom lines. At the other end of the tech sector spectrum, Henry Schien (HSIC) finished the session with respectable gains after the health care distributor beat analyst expectation on both the top and bottom line by a significant amount. On the slightly more absurd side of things, a Starbucks coffee cup made a fleeting, albeit accidental, cameo in one of the most recent episodes of the highly popular Game of Thrones television show, with producers not noticing the cups presence in the shot. Starbucks reportedly received ‘millions’ in free advertising and amid all the social media buzz, managed to finish the session only slightly in the red. Disney (DIS) managed to avoid the worst of the sell off, finishing the session flat amid the continued after-glow of another spectacular weekend of ‘Avengers: Endgame’ box office sales and the film maker announced dates for the next 3 Star Wars films. SPX -1.7% at 2884, NDX -2% at 7640, DJI -1.8% at 25966.

The Treasury curve bull-flattened on Tuesday, as risk aversion lent a bid to the complex. There was upside in the European morning after the European Commission's latest forecasts saw Germany growth view cut, while warning of Euro area risks. And in the European afternoon, the equity price slide gave a further boost to the T-Note. The US sold USD 38bln of 3-year notes, in a weak offering, which tailed by 0.7bps, and cover a touch softer than recent averages; direct bidders ended-up taking their largest share of a 3s auction since 2014. At settlement, major curve spreads were a touch flatter. US T-notes (M9) futures settled 12 ticks higher at 124-00+

US MARKET WRAP 7 MAY 2019: Stocks sink on risk aversion
content:
* SNAP SHOT: Equities down, Dollar up, Treasuries up, Crude down.

* REAR VIEW: Chinese Premier Li to travel to US for trade talks, US/Iran tensions escalate, Brexit talks continue without avail, decent US JOLTs and economic sentiment data

* COMING UP: RBNZ Cash rate Decision, SZ Unemployment Rate, GE Industrial Output, US MBA Mortgage Applications, CA House Starts, EIA Weekly Crude Stocks, BoE’s Ramsden, ECB’s Draghi, Fed’s Brainard, Riksbank’s Jochnik

* WEDNESDAY’S EARNINGS: US; MPC, DIS, FOXA, ODP, SAGE, EU; CBK, ENEL, WDI, SIE

* US/CHINA TRADE: China Vice Premier Liu He will travel to Washington at the tail-end of this week, in a sign China was looking-through threats by US President Trump, as well as US accusations of backpeddling on previously agreed points (weekend reports suggested that the Chinese had backtracked on promises to change its domestic laws to halt forced technology transfers). Some reports suggested that China's leadership decided a full breakdown in the talks may be difficult to repair, and would hit the Chinese economy. WSJ framed it as Chinese leaders break in away from a public position that Beijing would not negotiate under threat, impressing the importance of Liu He's visit this week. However, the patience may have a limit; China's Global Times editor (often used as a proxy for the China government's own position said "the possibility of an escalation of China-US trade war is seriously increasing, the situation is more tense than the Western media speculated." While there was a turnaround on Monday trade after traders suggested that the latest outburst from the President might just be rhetoric to try and speed up negotiations, his comments have been followed-up by other policy makers: US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said that 90% of the pact had been finalised, and the US was unwilling to re-negotiate previous commitments; Politico, citing sources, also reported that Senior White House officials described US President Trump as deadly serious about increasing the tariffs on China, and one senior official reportedly said "We have leverage. They have more to lose". Elsewhere, India is back in focus: US Commerce Secretary Ross notes that retaliation by India will not be appropriate if the US withdraws trade privileges for India, with the remarks following Ross' previous view that the trade imbalance with India must be addresses. And from the European perspective, EC President Juncker noted that nothing has changed on trade with the US since his last visit to Washington in July, adding that the EU can trust US President Trump on trade relations with the EU.

* BREXIT: UK PM May has been facing renewed calls to step-down as she attempts to secure a deal with Labour to break the Brexit deadlock. Some of her Tory party are concerned about her pivot towards a ("temporary") Customs Union - which has already been rejected in indicative votes, and would make it harder for the UK to negotiate trade deals with other nations. Ahead of her meeting with the influential backbench 1922 Committee, a member of that committee is said to have told the ITV that if chair Graham Brady returned from the meeting without a firm departure date for UK PM May, 'he will be sent back' - and as the meeting was occurring, reports emerged that the Committee is now tied on whether to change rules to remove PM May earlier than the one year grace period she had won after winning a confidence vote on her leadership (there was some suggestion May could take legal action to prevent this, though this was denied by the PM's spokesperson). Elsewhere, BBC said that key to achieving an agreement in the cross-party talks is the promise of this 'temporary customs union', though Labour sources have warned that if this is all there is, it is what is already encompassed in the Withdrawal Agreement. Nevertheless, other sources said that it is more likely now that Labour will do some kind of a deal, despite reports that a whole agreement has not yet been reached.

* US JOLTS: Jolts rebounded in March, following a decline in February. 7.488mln job openings were reported against a previous 7.142mln (upward revision). The job openings rate was up by 0.2ppts to 4.7%, the hiring rate was unchanged at 3.8%, the quits rate was unchanged at 2.3%, and the layoff rate fell 0.1ppts to 1.1%. The rebound in job openings was fairly broad based, but the latest JOLTS report still remains below the 2018Q4 average, Goldman Sachs noted.

* US IBD/TIPP: Economic optimism jumped to a 15-year high. "Despite political gamesmanship and partisan divides, Americans believe the economy is a clear bright spot," IBD said, "there have been ripples of uncertainty over the past several months, but with May's Economic Optimism Index hitting a 15-year high, consumers have seemingly moved past their doubts on the issue that directly impacts their pocketbook."

* FED: Fed's Clarida (Voter, Neutral) said the US economy was in a good place, and added that he sees temporary factors in recent soft inflation. Crucially, Clarida said the Fed does not see a strong case to move rates in either direction, echoing the remarks of Fed Chair Powell last week. The Fed's immediate focus was on getting inflation back to 2.0%, Clarida said, and the Fed will adjust policy accordingly in order to meet that objective. On trade, Clarida said it had not had a large economic impact so far. However, Fed's Kaplan (non-voter, dove), however, said trade uncertainty was impacting firms' supply chains, and he has concerns that global growth was decelerating. On rates, he toed the line, and said he would currently stand pat and doesn't see a need to lower rates to address inflation, while he doesn't have a bias for the direction of the next rate move. Kaplan also said he had been trying to flag issue of risky corporate debt which could be a burden on the economy in a downturn; and on the US economy, he expects it to remain healthy, and repeated that he does not see a recession coming, adding that the US should start to moderate debt growth.

* WTI (M9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 0.85 LOWER AT USD 61.40/BBL; BRENT (M9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 1.36 LOWER AT USD 69.88/BBL. Crude was lower on Tuesday, taking its cue from global risk sentiment (which was soggy, soured by the twist of tone in the US/China trade talks). US Energy Sec Perry said that Saudi Arabia was raising production in order to counter Iran sanctions impact, and said the message for US' allies around the world was clear: do not do business with Iran. Iran itself on Tuesday said that it was close to an oil sales deal with the EU, despite the re-imposition of US sanctions on buyers of Iranian crude. Following yesterday’s news that the US is to move an aircraft carrier to the Gulf region, news emerged that the US was also to send B-52 bomber to the region, whilst Iran made clear its intention to back off from the 2015 nuclear deal, and will announce ‘diminishing commitments’ to the deal on Wednesday. Regarding Russian oil supplies through the Druzhba Pipeline to Poland, though supplies through Germany remain suspended; the Russian energy minister Novak said he expects that the oil quality issue will have normalised in second half of May. Meanwhile, Russian April seaborne oil exports rose by 8.8% vs March. EIA STEO saw the organisation raise its forecast for 2019 global oil demand by +20k BPD (now sees a 1.38mln BPD Y/Y increase); for 2020, it raises forecast for global oil demand +80k BPD (to 1.53mln BPD Y/Y increase); The EIA forecasts US oil demand to rise +250k in 2019 (down from prior expectations of +360k rise), and by +280k in 2020 (up from prior expectations of +250k BPD rise). Meanwhile, it sees US crude output to +930k BPD in 2020 (compared to previous expectation of +710k BPD).

* SPX -1.7% at 2884, NDX -2% at 7640, DJI -1.8% at 25966. SECTORS: Communications -2%, Cons Discretionary -1.5%, Cons Staples -1%, Energy -0.6%, Financials -1.7%, Healthcare -1.9%, Industrials -2%, Materials -1.8%, Tech -2.1%, Telecoms -1.4%, Utilities -0.3%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Boeing (BA) shares were weighed down as the aircraft maker was downgraded at Barclays and faced criticism from American Airline pilots for poor communication regarding safety features on the 737 Max aircraft. American insurance Group (AIG) finished with strong gains as the insurer posted strong earnings. Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) were under pressure after reporting earnings that missed analyst expectations on both the top and bottom line. Allergan (AGN) also performed poorly on the day, despite reporting a beat on both the top and bottom lines. At the other end of the tech sector spectrum, Henry Schien (HSIC) finished the session with respectable gains after the health care distributor beat analyst expectation on both the top and bottom line by a significant amount. On the slightly more absurd side of things, a Starbucks coffee cup made a fleeting, albeit accidental, cameo in one of the most recent episodes of the highly popular Game of Thrones television show, with producers not noticing the cups presence in the shot. Starbucks reportedly received ‘millions’ in free advertising and amid all the social media buzz, managed to finish the session only slightly in the red. Disney (DIS) managed to avoid the worst of the sell off, finishing the session flat amid the continued after-glow of another spectacular weekend of ‘Avengers: Endgame’ box office sales and the film maker announced dates for the next 3 Star Wars films.

* US T-NOTES (M9) FUTURES SETTLE 12 TICKS HIGHER AT 124-00+: The Treasury curve bull-flattened on Tuesday, as risk aversion lent a bid to the complex. There was upside in the European morning after the European Commission's latest forecasts saw Germany growth view cut, while warning of Euro area risks. And in the European afternoon, the equity price slide gave a further boost to the T-Note. The US sold USD 38bln of 3-year notes, in a weak offering, which tailed by 0.7bps, and cover a touch softer than recent averages; direct bidders ended-up taking their largest share of a 3s auction since 2014. At settlement, major curve spreads were a touch flatter.

* FX WRAP: USD; the DXY was stronger on risk aversion, as scepticism build surrounding US/Sino trade negotiations; decent US JOLTs job openings and economic optimism data were background factors, doing little to drive price action despite firm readings. JPY was the star performer on the day; the European and US equites sell-off spurring flows into the safe haven asset, leading to USDJPY hitting fresh one-month lows. EUR; weakened in tango with a strengthening dollar on trade tensions concerns, with German Industrial order data, EC economic projections and comments from Salvini regarding the Italian deficit doing little to lift sentiment. AUD trades higher, with shorts squeezed after the RBA left rates unchanged overnight (there had been many calling for a rate cut at the meeting); the currency drifted lower through Europe and US trade on weak risk sentiment. NZD ahead of the RBNZ rate decision (40% chance of rate cut), the Kiwi traded lower, with global risk sentiment also weighing. Commodity FX were all under pressure as the crude complex fell.

Daily FX Wrap: Aussie and Yen buck weaker trend against the Greenback
content:
USD

The broad Dollar and DXY by default, are back on a firmer footing amidst ongoing uncertainty and concerns about the fate of US-China trade talks as the clock ticks down to Friday’s deadline for more widespread and punitive tariffs on Chinese goods. The index has rebounded from another sub-97.500 sortie ahead of key negotiations on Thursday and Friday that will either prevent another Usd200 bn Chinese goods being subject to an increased 25% tariff from 10% now or end in disharmony and potentially spark a full blown trade war. The DXY is just off a new session high of 97.722 and the Buck now firmer than all its major peers aside from the Aussie and Yen.

AUD/NZD/JPY 

The Aussie has erased almost all post-RBA gains vs its US counterpart and drifted back down closer to 0.7000 on the aforementioned heightened US-Chinese trade angst, but retains a solid advantage against the Kiwi above the 1.0600 handle on relative RBA/RBNZ policy outlooks given expectations that the NZ Cash Rate is more likely to be reduced overnight than the OCR. For a full preview of the forthcoming meeting check out the Ransquawk Research Suite and our headline feed nearer the event. Note, Nzd/Usd is currently sub-0.6600 with options pricing a break-even of circa 75 pips ahead of the RBNZ verdict. Elsewhere, Usd/Jpy continues to back off from recent 111.00 or close to the big figure highs through 110.50, but not quite far enough to threaten the top of an option expiry band spanning 110.00-40 in 1.3 bn.

CHF/GBP

Ending Tuesday’s EU session as the biggest G10 losers as the Franc slips back below 1.0200 vs the Dollar and 1.1425 against the single currency, while the Pound has been plagued by renewed Brexit-related jitters after the long UK holiday weekend as UK PM May resumes Cabinet meetings under pressure to name her departure date and cross-party talks continue with the Labour Party. Cable is back down below 1.3100 and not far from the next round number having breached the 100 HMA (1.3077), and Eur/Gbp has rebounded towards the top of a 0.8538-81 range and through the psychological 0.8550 level.

CAD/NOK/SEK

Also victims of the broad downturn in risk sentiment noted above, with the Loonie and Norwegian Krona also undermined by another retreat in crude prices and the Swedish Crown acknowledging weak new manufacturing orders alongside dovish Riksbank minutes. Usd/Cad is currently around 1.3475, Eur/Nok over 9.7800 and Eur/Sek above 10.7200 again.

EUR

A relative outperformer or at least displaying a degree of resistance vs the Usd within 1.1175-1.1220 trading parameters, with the 30 DMA (1.1226) capping the upside and decent option expiries at 1.1150 (1.1 bn) providing some underlying support in wake of more sub-forecast German data and EC projections downgrading GDP outlooks and raising Italy’s 2019 deficit estimate.

DOW

Boeing (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) Barclays downgrades to equal weight from overweight, now sees a longer recovery for the 737 Max; PT cut to USD 367 from USD 417. Separately, the Allied Pilots Association, which represents pilots working for American Airlines (AAL, Industrials/Airlines), has criticised BA, saying its confidence in the aircraft maker has been shaken after learning a safety feature on the 737 MAX aircraft didn't work as communicated.

Caterpillar (CAT) (Industrials/Construction Machinery & Heavy Trucks) miner Rio Tinto (RIO LN) to buy a fleet of autonomous trucks and other vehicles from CAT; Caterpillar will supply a fleet of 20 autonomous trucks and four autonomous blast drills for USD 2.6bln.

Goldman Sachs (GS) (Financials/Investment Banking & Brokerage) A federal judge said the DOJ is currently in plea talks with a former Goldman Sachs MD who was extradited from Malaysia after the 1MDB scandal; WSJ reported it was a development that could help prosecutors establish a case against the lender, and its employees in the scandal involving a Malaysian government fund. Elsewhere, global co-head of equity trade and execution Brian Levine to retire in the summer.

Walmart (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centres) in a blog said it will be opening more veterinary clinics in stores, and launching online pet pharmacy to rival that of Chewy.com (owned by PETS)

NASDAQ 100

Cognizant (CTSH) (Information Technology/IT Consulting & Other Services) expands research and development partnership with UK IT company Aveva (AVV LN) to develop industrial software.

KLA-Tencor (KLAC) (Information Technology/Semiconductor Equipment) (USD) reports Q3 adjusted EPS 1.80 (exp 1.67), revenue 1.097bln (exp 1.08bln).

Liberty Global PLC (LBTYA) (Telecommunications/Mass Media) (USD) reports Q1 revenues of 2.87bln (exp 2.81). Elsewhere, Vodafone (VOD LN) is stepping-up its battle to gain regulatory approval for its Liberty Global by offering rival Telefonica Deutschland (O2D GY) access to its enlarged high-speed broadband network. Vodafone last year agreed to pay USD 22bln for Liberty’s cable networks in Germany and central Europe.

Pepsi (PEP) (Consumer Staples/Soft Drinks) announced plans to invest USD 4bln in Mexico between 2019-2020.

Texas Instruments (TXN) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) VP Niels Anderskouv sold over USD 6.5mln of company shares, according to a filing.

American International Group (AIG) (Financials/Property & Casualty Insurance) (USD) Q1 adj EPS 1.58 (exp. 1.06).

Anadarko (APC) (Energy/Oil & Gas Exploration & Production) Board has determined that Occidental’s (OXY) revised offer was superior to Chevron’s (CVX). Occidental would acquire Anadarko for USD 59.00/shr in cash, and 0.2934 of a shares of Occidental common stock per share of Anadarko common stock. Occidental has obtained financing for the cash portion, completion of the transaction will not require or be conditioned upon the receipt of any vote or other approval by Occidental's stockholders. Anadarko has notified Chevron, and Anadarko intends to terminate the Chevron merger agreement. Chevron has the right up till 10 May 2019 where it may propose revisions, or to make another proposal.

BorgWarner (BWA) Consumer Discretionary/Auto Parts & Equipment) announces new joint venture with Romeo Power Technology (60/40 with BorgWarner obtaining the larger share), on battery pack business, initially focused on performance and light vehicles.

Centene Corp (CNC) (Health Care/Managed Health Care) Citi sees low likelihood of Centene walking from WellCare (WCG) deal. Amid the reports which suggest shareholders could challenge Centene's acquisition of WellCare, and Humana (HUM) possibly being interested in a takeover of Centene if the WellCare deal was dropped, Citi says he's be surprised to see the deal unravel, and would be equally surprised to see Humana come over the top for Centene after its Medicaid win in Florida and recent commentary citing optimism in its organic direction. However, analysts note that there is a scarcity of Medicaid assets, and Humana has discussed its interest in dual and other higher acuity Medicaid populations.

Emerson Electric Co (EMR) (Industrials/Electrical Components & Equipment) Q1 19 (USD): EPS 0.84 (exp. 0.84), Revenue 4.6bln (exp. 4.64bln). Narrows FY19 EPS view to between 3.60-3.70 (from 3.60-3.75, exp. 3.69), backs FY19 operating cash flow view USD 3.2bln, FCF at around USD 2.5bln; sees FY19 tax rate around 23% (prior view of 24%-25%).

Jacobs Engineering (JEC) (Industrials/Construction & Engineering) (USD) reports Q2 adj EPS 1.19 (exp 1.20), revenue 3.09bln (exp 3.1bln), raises FY19 adj EPS view to 4.45-4.85 from 4.40-4.80 (exp. 5.23).

Kinder Morgan (KMI) (Energy/Oil & Gas Storage & Transportation) The pipeline operator will pay a tariff on imported steel used in a USD 1.75bln pipeline project, Commerce Dept ruled saying that steel needed was available in the US, Reuters reported. Analysts estimate that the tariff could add USD 80mln to the construction of KMI’s Gulf Coast Express Pipeline.

Occidental (OXY) (Energy/Oil & Gas Exploration & Production) (USD) to acquire Anadarko (APC) assets in Africa for USD 8.8bln, contingent on Occidental (OXY) completing their acquisition of Anadarko.

Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) and Markel Corp. (MKL) (Financials/Insurance) The two will collaborate to create a branded insurance program, a step criticised by Berkshire Hathaway over the weekend.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 7th May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European Indices have drifted lower as the day progressed [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.6%], in-spite of reports that China’s VP Liu He is to attend trade talks in the US providing a boost to sentiment
  • In FX, AUD is outperforming after the RBA stood pat and were less Dovish than anticipated in their statement; remaining G10 currencies are little changed vs USD.
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US JOLTS EIA Short Term Energy Outlook, Fed's Kaplan & Quarles, BoE's Haldane, Supply from US

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equities traded mixed as sentiment remained at the whim of the ongoing US-China trade uncertainty with Nikkei 225 (-1.5%) and KOSPI (-0.9%) the underperformers on return from holiday closures as they got their first opportunity to react to US President Trump’s tariff threat. Nonetheless, there was no lack of success stories in Japan with Sony among the biggest gainers after having waited through a 10-day closure to finally benefit from a return to profit in Q4 and with SoftBank boosted as it considers an IPO for its USD 100bln Vision Fund. ASX 200 (+0.2%) was positive with the index led by strength in mining names and after mostly encouraging Trade Balance and Retail Sales data, while some participants were also hopeful for a rate cut by the RBA although this failed to materialize and subsequently saw the index give back some of the gains. Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.7%) nursed some of the prior day’s sell-off in which the mainland bourse had dropped nearly 6% due to the heightened trade tensions. Furthermore, the recovery also followed a substantial rebound on Wall St after reports that the China delegation will still travel to Washington D.C. provided a glimmer of hope, although this was later clouded after-hours as US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Trade Representative Lighthizer confirmed a deterioration in negotiations and that tariffs will be increased if there is no agreement by Friday. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher as the risk-averse tone in Tokyo spurred demand government bonds and with the BoJ also present in the market for JPY 940bln of JGBs.

PBoC injected CNY 20bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7614 (Prev. 6.7344)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer confirmed the US will increase tariffs on China on Friday if there is no deal and that China was reneging on commitments. Lighthizer also commented we have seen an erosion of commitments from China over the last week and that there has been no contact with China Vice Premier Liu He over the last 24 hours. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said US-China trade deal was 90% done and that talks saw a big change in direction. Mnuchin added that there were communications over the weekend that moved the agreement substantially backwards and that the US were in the process of planning a Trump-Xi summit, while he also suggested the US would reconsider the duties if talks get back on track. (Newswires)

 

Subsequently reported that, China's Vice Premier Liu He is to go the US for trade talks, for the 9th - 10th May, according to China. (Newswires) And the US side still has a willingness to reach a deal, China's delegation demonstrates their will by postponing the US trip. And Thursday will be the deceisive moment between US and China., according to the Editor of the Chinese Global Times. (Twitter)

US

Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter. Dove) said he would currently stand pat and doesn't see a need to lower rates to address inflation, while he added that he doesn't have a bias for the direction of the next rate move. Furthermore, Kaplan said he has been trying to flag issue of risky corporate debt which could be a burden on the economy in a downturn and is concerned global growth is decelerating. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM May is facing fresh calls from within her party to step down as she attempts to secure a deal with Labour to break the Brexit deadlock. (Times) These reports were also echoed by pieces in the Telegraph and Sky News. PM May is reportedly set to meet with the Graham Brady, Chair of the 1922 Committee today amid calls for her resignation. However, Downing Street insists that the meeting is routine. (BBC)

Key to achieving an agreement in Labour-Conservartive cross party talks on Brexit is the promise of a 'temporary customs union', though Labour sources warn that if this is all there is, it is what is already encompassed in the WA., BBC's Kuenssberg. (Twitter)

- Senior government source say it IS possible though to see a way to a deal, but unlikely to be resolved this week, adding that their aim is to path to get the Withdrawal Bill to Commons with a fair wind.

 

Brexit talks will take place behind closed doors today, cabinet will be followed by more cross-party talks but Opposition Labour Leader Corbyn will not be attending, according to Sky's Political Editor Rigby. (Twitter)

A member of the 1922 executive has stated that if Graham Brady returns from the meeting with PM May without a firm departure date he will be sent back., ITV's Brand. (Twitter)

- Additionally following the local elections the committee may look into changing leadership election rule

- Adds that the push if for a June departure date for PM May

 

Riksbank Minutes: members supported the picture of the economic outlook and inflation prospects described in the draft Monetary Policy Report

- Minor differences in opinion were expressed regarding when it might be appropriate to increase the rate next time but the forecast for the repo rate path indicates that it will raised at the end of the year or at the beginning of next year. In light of the unexpectedly low inflation both in Sweden and abroad

- Ingves says if the inflation rate in the euro area does not increase in the way described in their draft monetary policy report, then this may have a decisive effects on Swedish inflation and therefore Swedish monetary policy

EQUITIES

Major European indices are broadly in the red, and after drifted lower as the day has advanced [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.6%] in spite of risk sentiment receiving a boost prior to the cash open when China announced that Vice Premier Liu He is to attend trade talks in the US on the 9th & 10th of May. The FTSE 100 (-0.2%) is mildly lagging its peers as UK markets return from a bank holiday, and as such are reacting to the US-China trade updates; although, downside in the index is limited by the likes of Vodafone (+1.4%) and AstraZeneca (+1.5%) in the green after making a deal with Telefonica Deutschland (+2.2%) and announcing that their Phase 3 Calquence study achieved its primary endpoints respectively. Sectors are similarly mixed with energy names down in tandem with the oil complex, and notably the auto sector is once again in the red dragged down by heavyweight BMW (-1.0%) post-earnings. Following the Co. posted Q1 EBIT significantly lower than the prior levels and that the Co. have set aside EUR 1.4bln for anti-trust provisions after the Co. were previously warned of a significant charge resulting from an EU probe into collusion over delaying the implementation of cleaner-emissions cars. Other notable movers this morning include, AB Inbev (-0.1%) who at first fell around 1% at the open due to a slight miss on Q1 revenues and stating that short term dividend growth will be impacted deleveraging commitments. However, Co’s shares subsequently retraced much of this downside after stating that they are considering the IPO of their Asia-Pacific unit in Hong Kong, which could reportedly value the business at up to USD 40-70bln. In contrast, Infineon (-0.3%) initially moved higher by around 1.3% but gave up much of this surge as the Co. initially posted a beat on Q2 revenues but did emphasise that the market environment remains competitive.

FX

AUD/NZD - Aud/Usd is firmly back above 0.7000, albeit off overnight recovery highs circa 0.7050, while Aud/Nzd remains nearer the top of its range (1.0640+) having reclaimed 1.0600 status from a low of 1.0575 ahead of the eagerly awaited RBA policy meeting. In sum, the OCR was maintained at 1.5% and the accompanying statement struck a less dovish tone than most were anticipating as rate expectations were finely balanced between 51% for on hold and the remainder predicting a 25 bp ease. However, the Bank reiterated that strength in the labour market outweighed weakness in wages and inflation, supporting the decision to stand pat again and monitor data/economic developments (domestic and external). Conversely, Nzd/Usd has drifted back down towards 0.6600 as the spotlight switches to the RBNZ amidst even greater expectations that an ease is in the offing – see the Ransquawk headline feed for a more detailed preview.

SEK/NOK - The next best performing G10 currencies as the Swedish Krona rebounds from recent lows vs the Euro through 10.7000 on a broad stabilisation in risk sentiment and despite Riksbank minutes reaffirming the more dovish shift at the last policy meeting. Similarly, the Nok has pared losses to trade back above 9.7500 against the Eur and the backdrop of steadier oil prices.

EM - The Cnh is consolidating off Monday’s lows around 6.7750 vs 6.8000+ in wake of reports that China’s Vice Premier Lui will attend the next round of trade talks in Washington and the perception if not reality that his presence improves the chances that an agreement will be reached in time to avoid the 25% tariffs on a further Usd200 bn goods threatened by US President Trump over the weekend. However, this has not done much to lift the gloom for the Try as the Istanbul rerun is not due until June 23 and as such the uncertain domestic political scene will remain for another 1 1/2 months at least. The Lira has consolidated off a 6.2000 base vs the Dollar, but Turkish assets are still underperforming and looking vulnerable.

GBP/EUR/JPY/CAD - All relatively flat vs. the buck as news-flow somewhat slowed in EU trade, albeit Brexit remains in the background with Labour leader Corbyn not partaking to today’s cross-party talks, whilst PM May is speculated to receive her departure date before the 1922 committee. Sky News’ Rigby did however note that prospects have increased for a cross-party deal, citing a Cabinet source. Cable largely was unreactive to a technical speech by Cunliffe on post-Brexit financial stability. GBP/USD remains below the 1.3100 handle (having fallen below its 50 DMA around the figure), with the next technical at its 100 HMA at 1.3077. Elsewhere, the single currency remains just around the 1.1200 level, with the European Commission Spring Forecast pushed back to around 11:30BST due to an earlier speech by the Commission’s President. The focus of the release will be Italy as press reported that the EC may warn of widening Italian budget deficit to 2.6% of GDP, above the government’s forecast of 2.4%. Moving on, the Loonie straddles just below 1.3500 vs. the Greenback ahead of Ivey PMIs later. Elsewhere, JPY remains sub-111 vs. the Buck, holding onto most of its post-Trump risk premia ahead of further trade talks this week with Vice Premier Liu He now attending, signalling high-level talks. USD/JPY remains flat around 110.50 with around 1.3bln in option expiries around 110.00-40.

FIXED INCOME

More decent block buying in the belly of the US Treasury curve is representative if not catalytic in terms of a broad and firm rebound in debt futures that has seen Bunds forge a new Eurex intraday high at 165.80, +36 ticks vs -20 ticks in wake of Lui He low, while Gilts have pushed on further with the initial catch-up baton to hit 127.36. Further ahead, traders are now eyeing upcoming comments from BoE’s Cunliffe ahead of Fed’s Kaplan and Quarles later in the day; with US JOLTS and USD 38bln in supply also on the docket.

COMMODITIES

Brent (-0.6%) and WTI (-0.4%) prices are somewhat subdued, but have been relatively steady and are currently trading within a very narrow USD 1/bbl range this morning. News flow for the complex has been relatively light, with prices largely moving in-line with the US-China driven sentiment. However, there were reports that Israel has provided the White House with intelligence regarding a potential Iranian plot to target US interest in the Gulf. Looking ahead, we have the API weekly inventory report with expectations for crude inventories to increase by 2.5mln barrels; additionally, the EIA are releasing their Short Term Energy Outlook, where they previously forecast that the US crude oil production is to average 12.4mln BPD in 2019 and 13.1mln BOD in 2020. For reference, EIA weekly crude production stood at 12.3mln BPD in last week’s release.

Gold (U/C) prices are largely unchanged on the day, with the safe haven selling off slightly following China stating that Vice Premier Liu He is to attend trade talks in the US. With the yellow metal still holding firm above the USD 1280/oz level, currently around USD 1281/oz. Elsewhere, Vale state that the Brucutu mining complex has stopped operations due to a court decision; follows on from a prior lower court decision which had stated that mining activities could resume.

LME are in talks with Chinese authorities to open its first metal warehouse in the country. (FT)

Russian oil quality from the Baltic Sea port of UST-Luga is seeing a major improvement, though the quality is still fluctuating sharply day-to-day; though supplies via the Druzhba pipeline to Poland and Germany are still suspended., according to sources. (Newswires)

Russian Energy Minister Novak says the commission has determined the source of the Russian oil contamination, 4 people have been detained regarding the contamination. (Newswires)

- Adds that they expect clean oil to reach the UST-Luga port on May 8th

- Proposed tougher regulation on oil quality control

- Expects the oil situation to be normalised in the second half of May

subject: Regeneron Pharmaceuticals Inc (REGN) Q1 19 (USD): Non-GAAP EPS 4.45 (exp. 5.46), Revenue 1.71bln (exp. 1.76bln)
Nomura quants say it would be wise to remain wary of Monday's stock rally
content:
• The bank notes that while S&P 500 E-mini fell sharply during Asian trading hours on 6/May, it rallied during NY trading hours, ending the day down only slightly. "We think it would be wise to remain wary, however," Nomura says, "as fresh doubt has been cast on a positive resolution to US-China trade tensions."
  • Nomura says it has noted an interesting behavioural pattern of short-term investors: "most trend-following short-term investors (CTAs, risk-parity funds etc.) have stopped bidding the market higher, and CTAs have pivoted to a wait-and-see stance for the moment," Nomura writes, "but we think they may start to defensively unwind their long positions depending on where the market heads and the extent of market volatility, as we estimate that the break-even level of their positions (established through their cumulative net buying since the end of March) is around 2,915 for the S&P 500 and 8,030 for the NASDAQ Composite."
  • Nomura also says that discretionary players (global macro HFs, equity L/S funds, etc.) had for the most part not been actively chasing the market higher in the first place, and thus handily dodged the sell-off. "Global macro HFs in particular have taken profits on their short positions in US stocks, and this short covering by contrarians actually lent some support to the market."

subject: Gilts hold firm after long weekend, Short Sterling futures overcome early wobble
content: The 10 year UK benchmark reclaimed 127.00+ status on its return to Liffe after yesterday’s bank holiday, largely in corrective trade having missed out on the US President tariff tirade and ensuing safe-haven rally in core counterparts. Gilts have been probing higher within an early 127.09-28 range following an initial mark-up to 127.13 vs last Friday’s 126.93 settlement and the bullish tone appears to have encouraged the 3 month STIR strip to overturn earlier losses of 0.5-1 tick and forge gains of 0.5 to 2 ticks at present. US-China trade issues aside, Brexit is back in the spotlight as PM May meets back-benchers and continues talks with Labour, while scheduled speeches from BoE’s Cunliffe and Haldane will also be eyed for anything new or contrary to policy guidance delivered on ‘super Thursday’.

subject: Riksbank Minutes: members supported the picture of the economic outlook and inflation prospects described in the draft Monetary Policy Report
content:
• Minor differences in opinion were expressed regarding when it might be appropriate to increase the rate next time but the forecast for the repo rate path indicates that it will raised at the end of the year or at the beginning of next year. In light of the unexpectedly low inflation both in Sweden and abroad
  • Several members noted that the global economy is still fraught with uncertainty and risks that can lead to poorer development going forward
  • Ingves says if the inflation rate in the euro area does not increase in the way described in their draft monetary policy report, then this may have a decisive effects on Swedish inflation and therefore Swedish monetary policy

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

7th May 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equities traded mixed as sentiment remained at the whim of the ongoing US-China trade uncertainty with Nikkei 225 (-1.5%) and KOSPI (-0.9%) the underperformers on return from holiday closures as they got their first opportunity to react to US President Trump’s tariff threat. Nonetheless, there was no lack of success stories in Japan with Sony among the biggest gainers after having waited through a 10-day closure to finally benefit from a return to profit in Q4 and with SoftBank boosted as it considers an IPO for its USD 100bln Vision Fund. ASX 200 (+0.3%) was positive with the index led by strength in mining names and after mostly encouraging Trade Balance and Retail Sales data, while some participants were also hopeful for a rate cut by the RBA although this failed to materialize and subsequently saw the index give back some of the gains. Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) nursed some of the prior day’s sell-off in which the mainland bourse had dropped nearly 6% due to the heightened trade tensions. Furthermore, the recovery also followed a substantial rebound on Wall St after reports that the China delegation will still travel to Washington D.C. provided a glimmer of hope, although this was later clouded after-hours as US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Trade Representative Lighthizer confirmed a deterioration in negotiations and that tariffs will be increased if there is no agreement by Friday.

FTSE

Gambling Names – Co’s will be required to verify customers are 18 before funds are placed into an account, online operators will additionally have to verify customers names and addresses in rules from the Gambling Commission which come into effect on Tuesday. (FT)

BT (BT/A LN) – Co’s CEO Jansen reportedly favours reducing shareholder pay-outs as Openreach increases the roll out of faster and more reliable fibre networks, however, the Co’s Chairman Plessis reportedly prefers to maintain the Co’s dividend and his own standing; as he has previously insisted that new leadership would not result in another change to pay-outs. Separately, Co’s CEO is to begin his tenure by instigating a bolder approach to fibre investment, expected to be unveiled on Thursday when the Co. are due to report their earnings. (Telegraph/FT)

Severn Trent (SNT LN) – UK Labour leader Corbyn stated that a future Labour government would offer shareholders in UK water Utilities GBP 20bln in a nationalisation programme, which compares with the current market value of approximately GBP 44bln. (Twitter/Times/Newswires)

Whitbread (WTB LN) – Shareholder Elliott has called for the Co. to offload parts of its GBP 5.8bln property portfolio. (Newswires)

BAE (BAE/ LN) – Co’s systems sensor technology guides next generation missiles, Co. and Lockheed Martin recently signed a contract to produce over 50 sensors. (Newswires)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – Co’s Calquence Phase 3 has achieved its primary endpoints. (Newswires)

 

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Metro Bank (MTRO LN) – Co.’s rights offering is reportedly to be priced at GBP 4-4.50/shr. (Newswires)

G4S (GFS LN) – Garda World Security has announced that they do not intend to make an offer for the Co. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PERSIMMON (PSN LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM NEUTRAL AT CITI

DAX

Henkel (HEN GY) – Q1 revenue EUR 4.97bln vs. Prev. EUR 4.84bln, adj. EBIT EUR 795mln vs. Prev. EUR 842mln Co. affirms their FY19 adj. EPS, organic sales and EBIT margin. (Newswires)

BMW (BMW GY) – Q1 sales EUR 22.46bln vs. Exp. EUR 22.6bln, Q1 EBIT EUR 589mln vs. Prev. EUR 2.71bln. Co. have revised anti-trust provisions to EUR 1.4bln. Q1 EPS 0.85, EBIT loss of EUR 310mln. Co. states that their operational performance is on track though they expect tailwinds in H2. (Newswires)

Infineon (IFX GY) – Q2 net income EUR 231mln, Q2 revenue EUR 1.9bln. Q2 EPS USD 0.24 vs. Exp. USD 0.22. Co. states that Q2 revenue and earnings are in-line with their expectations but the challenging market environment remains. (Newswires)

Vonovia (VNA GY) – Q1 adj. EBITDA EUR 430ln vs. Prev. EUR 333mln and FFO EUR 303.6mln and Prev. EUR 244mln. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Hannover RE (HNO1 GY) – Q1 net income EUR 293.7mln vs. Exp. EUR 288.2mln, EBIT EUR 450mln vs. Exp. EUR 434.2mln. Co. confirm FY19 profit guidance. (Newswires)

Uniper (UN01 GY) – Q1 revenue EUR 21.83bln. Q1 net income EUR 791mln, Adj. EBIT EUR 185mln, -47.3%. Co. confirms FY19 forecasts and dividend targets. Q1 adverse factors were weaker gas and LNG business, and other temporary effect in European power generation. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

HOCHTIEF (HOT GY) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT KEPLER CHEUVREUX

DEUTSCHE POST (DPW GY) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT BERENBERG

CAC

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Alstom (ALO FP) – FY19 revenue EUR 8.1bln vs. Exp. EUR 8.11bln. Co. state they have an outstanding order intake level at EUR 12.1bln, resulting in a record level backlog of EUR 40.5mln. Co. propose a dividend of EUR 5.50 per share, and state that results support the success of the 2020 strategy plan (Newswires)

EssilorLuxottica (EL FP) – Q1 revenue EUR 4.12bln vs. Exp. EUR 4.18bln, Co. confirm their FY19 targets. Synergies are expected to range from EUR 420-600mln impact on adj. operating profit. (Newswires)

JCDecaux (DEC FP) – Co. have secured an exclusive advertising deal for 10 years for the Abu Dhabi International Airports midfield terminal. (Newswires)

Euronext (ENX FP) – Co. have extended the acceptance period on their offer for Oslo Bors, with all other terms remaining unchanged. (Newswires)

STMicroelectronics (STM FP) – Co. and Air Liquid (AI FP) are to collaborate on a digital transformation. (Newswires)

Arkema (AKE FP) – Q1 revenue EUR 2.22bln vs. Prev. EUR 2.17bln, EBITDA EUR 370mln vs. Prev. EUR 383mln and net EUR 165mln vs. Prev. EUR 195mln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SOCGEN (GLE FP) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT DZ BANK

PAN EUROPE

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) – Co. state that they see F2I’s bid for the broadcasting unit Persidera as fair, according to a source. (Newswires)

PostNL (PNL NA) – Q1 revenue EUR 684mln vs. Exp. EUR 690mln and operating profit EUR 31mln vs. Exp. EUR 31mln. Co. state they confirm their FY19 UCOI outlook at EUR 170-200mln, from 2020 the Co’s outlook is to be based on free cash flow and normalised EBIT. Co. state that normalised EBIT is anticipated to increase. (Newswires)

DSM (DSM NA) – Q1 revenue EUR 2.29bln vs. Exp. EUR 2.3bln, adj. EBITDA EUR 424ln vs. Exp. EUR 401mln. Co. increases their Fy19 guidance to high-single digits. (Newswires)

AB Inbev (ABI BB) – Q1 revenue USD 12.59bln vs. Exp. USD 12.77bln, normalised EBITDA USD 4.99bln vs. Exp. USD 5.06bln. Q1 total volumes 133.5mln HLS vs. Prev. 134.8mln HLS. Co. state they are to continue delivering strong results in 2019, expect dividends to grow over time but will be at a modest rate in the short term due to deleveraging commitments. Co. confirm they are considering the sale of their Asia-Pacific unit via Hong Kong IPO. (Newswires)

Solvay (SOLB BB) – Q1 revenue EUR 2.57bln vs. Prev. EUR 2.49bln, adj. EBITDA EUR 571mln vs. Exp. EUR 564. 4mln and net EUR 228mln vs. Prev. EUR 107mln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

BANCO SABADELL (SAB SM) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM EQUAL WEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

MAPFRE (MAP SM) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM NEUTRAL AT JP MORGAN CHASE

SMI

Adecco (ADEN SW) – Q1 revenue EUR 5.65bln vs. Exp. EUR 5.64bln, adj. EBITA EUR 226mln, EBITA EUR 221mln. Co. states that growth trends in Europe stabilising, America have slowed and the ROW has accelerated. Co. add that they are on track to achieve additional savings of EUR 70mln. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA 

BROKER MOVES

EQUINOR (EQNR NO) REITERATED OUTPERFORM AT RBC

TELE2 (TEL2 SS) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT HSBC

US

* SPX -0.4% at 2933, NDX -0.7% at 7794, DJI -0.3% at 26437. SECTORS: Communications -0.8%, Cons Discretionary -0.6%, Cons Staples -0.2%, Energy -0.1%, Financials -0.7%, Healthcare +0.6%, Industrials -1%, Materials -1.4%, Tech -0.8%, Telecoms -0.2%, Utilities -0.6%.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 7th May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equities traded mixed as sentiment remained at the whim of the ongoing US-China trade uncertainty
  • US Trade Representative Lighthizer confirmed the US will increase tariffs on China on Friday if there is no deal and that China was reneging on commitments
  • UK PM May is facing fresh calls from within her party to step down as she attempts to secure a deal with Labour to break the Brexit deadlock
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German Industrial Orders, US JOLTS, EU Commission Economic Forecasts, EIA Short Term Energy Outlook, Fed's Kaplan & Quarles, BoE's Cunliffe & Haldane, Supply from US & Germany (I/L)
  • Earnings: Allergan, Regeneron Pharmaceuticals, AB Inbev, BMW, Infineon

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equities traded mixed as sentiment remained at the whim of the ongoing US-China trade uncertainty with Nikkei 225 (-1.5%) and KOSPI (-0.9%) the underperformers on return from holiday closures as they got their first opportunity to react to US President Trump’s tariff threat. Nonetheless, there was no lack of success stories in Japan with Sony among the biggest gainers after having waited through a 10-day closure to finally benefit from a return to profit in Q4 and with SoftBank boosted as it considers an IPO for its USD 100bln Vision Fund. ASX 200 (+0.3%) was positive with the index led by strength in mining names and after mostly encouraging Trade Balance and Retail Sales data, while some participants were also hopeful for a rate cut by the RBA although this failed to materialize and subsequently saw the index give back some of the gains. Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) nursed some of the prior day’s sell-off in which the mainland bourse had dropped nearly 6% due to the heightened trade tensions. Furthermore, the recovery also followed a substantial rebound on Wall St after reports that the China delegation will still travel to Washington D.C. provided a glimmer of hope, although this was later clouded after-hours as US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Trade Representative Lighthizer confirmed a deterioration in negotiations and that tariffs will be increased if there is no agreement by Friday. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher as the risk-averse tone in Tokyo spurred demand government bonds and with the BoJ also present in the market for JPY 940bln of JGBs.

PBoC injected CNY 20bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7614 (Prev. 6.7344)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer confirmed the US will increase tariffs on China on Friday if there is no deal and that China was reneging on commitments. Lighthizer also commented we have seen an erosion of commitments from China over the last week and that there has been no contact with China Vice Premier Liu He over the last 24 hours. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said US-China trade deal was 90% done and that talks saw a big change in direction. Mnuchin added that there were communications over the weekend that moved the agreement substantially backwards and that the US were in the process of planning a Trump-Xi summit, while he also suggested the US would reconsider the duties if talks get back on track. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM May is facing fresh calls from within her party to step down as she attempts to secure a deal with Labour to break the Brexit deadlock. (Times) These reports were also echoed by pieces in the Telegraph and Sky News. PM May is reportedly set to meet with the Graham Brady, Chair of the 1922 Committee today amid calls for her resignation. However, Downing Street insists that the meeting is routine. (BBC)

 

ECB's Chief Economist Praet said tiered deposit rates need to have a monetary policy reason and emphasised that care must be taken with any monetary policy strategy review. (Newswires)

 

FX

 

The DXY was slightly softer and traded just below 97.50 amid mild gains in its major counterparts in which EUR/USD reclaimed the 1.1200 handle and with GBP/USD back above 1.3100. However, upside in GBP was capped as participants look ahead to the resumption of business in Westminster following the long weekend, with PM May facing fresh calls to resign from within her party and was also said to have been warned that MPs will attempt to oust her as early as this week if she agrees to Labour proposals for a customs union deal with the EU. AUD/USD firmed amid strength in iron ore prices and following mostly encouraging data from Australia, with upside later exacerbated after the RBA kept rates unchanged, noted a strong labour market and refrained from adopting a clear easing bias as some had suggested. USD/JPY was subdued below 111.00 as the risk averse tone in Japan acted as a restraint, while TRY suffered heavily to print its weakest since October due to political concerns after Turkey’s High Election Board ruled to re-run the Istanbul local elections which the opposition party had won.

 

RBA kept the Cash Rate Target unchanged at 1.50% in what was seen as very close call, as markets had priced in a 51% probability for rates to be kept on hold vs. 49% chances of a 25bps cut. RBA said it will pay close attention to the labour market in approaching meetings and that the labour market remains strong, while it added there is still spare capacity in the economy and that there had been some pick up in in wages growth. However, the RBA also stated Q1 inflation data was noticeably lower than expected and that main domestic uncertainty remains around household spending as well as falling house prices. (Newswires)

 

Australian Trade Balance (AUD)(Mar) 4.95B vs. Exp. 4.30B (Prev. 4.80B Rev. 5.14B). (Newswires)

Australian Retail Sales MM (Mar) 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.8%)

Australian Retail Trade (Q1) -0.1% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.1%)

 

BoC Governor Poloz said that Chinese moves against Canadian canola and pork exports are downside risks to the Canadian economy and cannot say now if this risk will become long-term. (Newswires)

Turkey's High Election Board ruled to re-run the Istanbul local elections on the grounds that some of the ballot box officials were not actually civil servants with the rerun to be held on 23rd June. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were steady overnight amid the mixed risk tone with WTI crude flat above the USD 62.00/bbl level after the prior day’s rebound from support around USD 60.00/bbl with the recovery also attributed to increasing tensions between US and Iran with reports suggesting the US received intelligence about a potential Iranian plot to attack US interests in the Gulf. Elsewhere, gold saw mild upside due to the lacklustre greenback and copper plateaued overnight amid the mixed risk tone due to US-China trade uncertainty, while iron prices were underpinned on supply concerns after the resumption of Vale’s Brucutu mine was halted.

GEOPOLITICS 

US Secretary of State Pompeo said the US continues to see Iranian activity that suggests an escalation, while reports noted that Israel passed intelligence to the White House about a potential Iranian plot to attack US interests in the Gulf. (Newswires/Axios)

US

After the US President threw his trade toys out of the pram over the weekend, volumes and therefore moves were lacklustre as fixed income traders saw little reward to trading the now binary possibilities of a US/Sino deal/no deal (in addition to multiple market holidays). As such treasuries saw little volatility as the President’s huffing and puffing gave a tailwind to fixed income futures, which steadily climbed throughout the session in thin ranges. Harker also failed to add impetus after largely reiterating Fed guidance, stating that inflation dampening effects are likely transitory, and saw 10yrs close with gains of around 9 ticks and the curve moderately steeper. As such traders are likely looking ahead to a trading week set to be chock-full of trade talk deliberations and upcoming USD 84bln worth of supply this week kicked off by USD 38bln in 3yrs tomorrow. US T-note futures (M9) settled 9 ticks higher at 123-20+

Fed reportedly sees trade tensions as the preeminent short-term risk although it sees financial risks little changed since last fall as the sector appears resilient, while it added that risk appetite remains elevated and overall leverage remains low. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter. Dove) said he would currently stand pat and doesn't see a need to lower rates to address inflation, while he added that he doesn't have a bias for the direction of the next rate move. Furthermore, Kaplan said he has been trying to flag issue of risky corporate debt which could be a burden on the economy in a downturn and is concerned global growth is decelerating. (Newswires)

Trade US President Trump tweeted that the US has been losing USD 600bln-800bln on trade and loses USD 500bln with China which he suggested will not happen anymore. (Twitter)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer confirmed the US will increase tariffs on China this Friday if there is no deal and that China was reneging on commitments. Lighthizer also commented we have seen an erosion of commitments from China over the last week and that there has been no contact with China Vice Premier Liu He over the last 24 hours. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said US-China trade deal was 90% done and that talks saw a big change in direction. Mnuchin added that there were communications over the weekend that moved the agreement substantially backwards and that the US were in the process of planning a Trump-Xi summit, while he also suggested the US would reconsider the duties if talks get back on track. (Newswires)

China delegation will still travel to the US for trade talks despite US President Trump's threats, according to sources. (CNBC) 

Other News - About 75% of companies listed in China’s National Equities Exchange and Quotation market or “new third board” reported year-on-year increase in net profits for 2018. (China Economic Times)
